fr:mainmatter.html:p: A locally distributed space (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) is a scheme, if for any x\in X there is an open neighbourhood U of x, such that (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is an affine scheme. The full subcategory of schemes will be denoted as \mathbf {Sch}_{\mathbb {D}}.
It is well-known that if X is a scheme, then as a topological space it is sober and locally compact. However, it may fail to be quasi-separated or compact.
Let X be a scheme, U an open subset of X. Then (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is again a scheme. There is a canonical inclusion U \hookrightarrow X. Morphisms of this form are called open immersion.

The disjoint union X \cong \coprod _{i\in I}X_i of arbitrary schemes is again a scheme. The structural sheaf on an open U is given by \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \cong \prod _{i\in I}\mathcal {O}_{X_i}(U \cap X_i). They are indeed the coproducts in \mathbf {Sch}_{\mathbb {D}}.

In fact, we can compute the global section of \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+. Under Proposition , it as an open subset corresponds to the maximal ideal M = \mathbb {H}[x]-\{1\}. This way under Proposition , \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+} \cong \mathbb {H}[x]_M \cong \mathbb {H}[x]. The final isomorphism is an easy exercise. This means the open immersion \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] induces an isomorphism on global section.

fr:title.text: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A scheme X is affine iff its underlying topological space is spectral, i.e. iff it is compact and quasi-separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let X be a scheme whose underlying topological space is spectral. Let D be the distributive lattice of compact open subsets of X. Let \{U_i\}_{i\in I} be a finite family of affine open covers of X. For any U_i, since U_i is affine, and affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological space (see Remark ), we must have \mathcal {O}_{U_i} \cong D_i where D_i is the principle quotient of D corresponding to the compact open U_i. This way, \mathcal {O}_{X} and \mathcal {O}_{D} agree on this open cover, which implies that \mathcal {O}_{X} \cong \mathcal {O}_{D}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: As a corollary of Theorem , if a scheme X is finite, then it is affine, since finite sober spaces are all spectral.

For a distributive lattice D, the structural sheaf \mathcal {O}_{D} on \operatorname {Spec} D is given as follows: For each basic open O_p of \operatorname {Spec} D, which we may simply write as p, we define \mathcal {O}_{D}(p) := D/p. For q \le p, we put the restriction map to be q \wedge - : \mathcal {O}_{D}(p) \cong D/p \twoheadrightarrow D/q \cong \mathcal {O}_{D}(q).

If \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf, then at each prime filter x\in \operatorname {Spec} D, the stalk of \mathcal {O}_{D} at x is given by \mathcal {O}_{D,x} \cong \operatorname {colim}_{p\in x}D/p \cong D/x. As a distributive lattice this is local by Proposition .

fr:title.text: Structural sheaf is a sheaf for Zariski topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structural sheaf is a sheaf for Zariski topology

fr:mainmatter.html:p: \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf of distributive lattices on \operatorname {Spec} D, which is local as an internal distributive lattice.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We verify the sheaf condition. Again since O_p \cong \operatorname {Spec} D/p, we only need to verify the sheaf condition on the total space \operatorname {Spec} D. By compactness, let us consider a finite union \operatorname {Spec} D = \bigcup _{i\le n}O_{p_i} = O_{\bigvee _{i\le n}p_i}, which is equivalent to the fact that \bigvee _{i\le n}p_i = 1. Now suppose we have a compatible family of elements q_i \in D_{p_i} for all i. Compatibility means q_i \wedge p_j = q_j \wedge p_i, for all i,j\le n. This way, we construct the element q := \bigvee _{i\le n} q_i. Firstly, indeed we have q \wedge p_j = \bigvee _{i\le n}q_i \wedge p_j = \bigvee _{i\le n} q_j \wedge p_i = q_j \wedge \bigvee _{i\le n}p_i = q_j. Thus q is indeed an amalgamation of \{q_i\}_{i\le n}. For uniqueness, suppose we have q' with q' \wedge p_i = q_i for all i. Then we have q' = \bigvee _{i\le n} q' \wedge p_i = \bigvee _{i\le n} q \wedge p_i = q. Hence, \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf. It is local as an internal distributive lattice because at each point x\in \operatorname {Spec} D, the stalk by Remark is \mathcal {O}_{D,x} \cong D/x, thus local.

fr:title.text: Partial element of a distributive lattice

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Partial element of a distributive lattice

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a distributive lattice D and an ideal I, an I-element of D is a function u : I \to D satisfying for any i\in I and a\in D, u(i \wedge a) = u(i) \wedge a. The set of I-elements of D will be denoted as D_I.

fr:title.text: Structural sheaf on a general open

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structural sheaf on a general open

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any distributive lattice D, we use I to denote the open set O_I via Proposition . Then \mathcal {O}_{D}(I) \cong D_I.
A locally distributed space is a pair (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}), where X is a topological space and \mathcal {O}_{X} is a sheaf of local distributive lattice on X.

A morphism f : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (Y,\mathcal {O}_{Y}) between locally distributed spaces is a continuous function f : X \to Y, together with a local morphism f^{\sharp } : f^*\mathcal {O}_{Y} \to \mathcal {O}_{X}. Here f^{\sharp } is local iff it is t-conservative. The category of locally distributed spaces will be denoted as \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}}.

fr:title.text: Spec as a functor to locally distributed spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Spec as a functor to locally distributed spaces

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The functor \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Spec} given in Theorem can be extended to one \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}}

On the other hand, we need to show that for any morphism between locally distributed spaces (f,f^{\sharp }) : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (\operatorname {Spec} D,\mathcal {O}_{D}), it is determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Fistly, since D\twoheadrightarrow D/p is a localisation, all the morphisms f_{\sharp } : D/p \to _{\sharp } X(f^{-1} p) are already determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Hence, it suffices to show that f is also determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. The key of course is the requirement that f^{\sharp } is t-conservative. By the Kripke-Joyal semantics, this means that for any x\in X, the induced map on stalk D/fx \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x} must be t-conservative. This uniquely determines fx since \mathcal {O}_{X,x} by construction is local, and has a unique prime filter. This then determines fx by looking at the preimage D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x}.
We will denote the objects of \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}} that lies in the image of \operatorname {Spec} as affine schemes.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Since \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Spec} is an equivalence, affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological spaces.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the free distributive lattice 2[I] over a poset I, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] \cong \mathcal {U}(I). For any x\in \mathcal {U}(I), \mathcal {O}_{2[I],x} \cong 2[I]/x \cong 2[I-x]. Hence, the stalks of \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] are also free.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a bounded linear order L, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} L \cong \mathcal {U}_+(L). For any upward closed subset x of L, we have \mathcal {O}_{L,x} \cong \operatorname {colim}_{p\in x}L/p \cong L/x, where L/x is simply the quotient of L by identifying x with 1 and the others remaining the same. In particular, each stalk is again a linear lattice.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the distributive lattice \mathbb {N} given in Example , recall its prime spectral corresponds to prime power p^k, and 0. The corresponding prime filter F_{p^k} is the set of numbers not containing p^k as a factor, and F_0 is the set of positive numbers. This way, we have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},p^k} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{p^k} \cong \{0 < \cdots < p^{k+2} < p^{k+1} < p^{k} < 1\} \cong \overline {\omega }^{\mathrm {op}}. consisting of the infinite descending sequence of powers of p, and \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},0} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{0} \cong 2. Notice that all the stalks are linear. Since linearity is a geometric condition, it follows that \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N}} is a linear distributive lattice over \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {N}. However, \mathbb {N} is by no means linear.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the sub distributive lattice \mathbb {P} of \mathbb {N} described in Example , its prime spectrum can be identified as primes, plus 0. For any prime p the stalk now kills of all higher powers of p and is simply given by \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},p} \cong \{0 < p < 1\} \cong 2[x], and we also have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},0} \cong 2. \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P}} is thus again a linear distributive lattice.
